confident that the text is written entirely by a human.', 'document_classification': 'HUMAN_ONLY', 'version': '2025-01-09-base', 'language': 'en', 'pageNumber': 0, 'inputText': 'Photo: Getty Images A massive "devil comet" reported to be three times the size of Mount Everest is hurtling towards Earth. The 12P/Pons-Brooks cryovolcanic comet has exploded and is reportedly expected to be closest to Earth in June 2024, experts told ABC News. The comet, which is estimated to have a diameter of at least 17 kilometers (10.5 miles), is described as being unusually bright compared to others and could possibly be visible to the naked eye at its closest point. The 12P/Pons-Brooks undergoes huge increases in brightness after two major eruptions -- having undergone the first in July 2023 and the second earlier this month -- unlike most other comets, which typically get warmer and brighter as they get closer to the sun, turning ice to gas and pulling dust away. "These outbursts … [have] brought this object from being dim enough that you can only really see it with big professional telescopes to, in a couple of cases, something people can see from their backyard," said Dr. Theodore Kareta, a postdoctoral researcher at the Lowell Observatory in Flagstaff, Arizona, via ABC News. "There aren\'t that many comets that have outbursts, these sudden increases in brightness, that are so strong, and even fewer that have them a couple of times during one orbit. It seems like Pons-Brooks ... is just really active," he added. The coma of the comet -- the fuzzy cloud around its nucleus -- has a shape resembling two "devil horns," which defers greatly from most other comets. The 12P/Pons-Brooks is not usually visible, but could be as it passes over the United States, Canada and Mexico during a total solar eclipse on April 8, 2024.'}]

'HUMAN_ONLY', 'version': '2025-01-09-base', 'language': 'en', 'pageNumber': 0, 'inputText': "Photo: Getty Images Bumper stickers and window decals have always been a fun way for some drivers to express their personality and customize their car. Whether it's a silly phrase or a meaningful quote, most people apply the stickers without a second thought, but police are warning drivers that some stickers could be putting them, and their families, in significant danger. The biggest culprit is a decal you probably see daily and might even have on your own vehicle - the one showing stick figure versions of all the members of the car owner's family. The stickers now come in different varieties, including ones that portray an activity every family member is into, and some decals even include each person's name. Occasionally, there might be a separate bumper sticker revealing the school or schools younger family members attend, perhaps out of school pride or as a boast if someone in the fam is on the honor roll there. The issue with it all is that it gives criminals loads of information to use in nefarious ways. Photo: OhioSAR.org While kids are taught all about stranger danger, they might not think a person is a stranger if that person knows their name. Sites where the stickers can be purchased even suggest against putting names under figures on the decals, but many people just ignore the warning. Because of all the danger, police are now urging car owners to not put up stickers that give away personal information. The authorities also advise going even further and removing any parking passes that might hang from a rearview mirror when the car isn't parked in the lot it's required for. Additionally, the police warn against putting a child's name on their backpacks or clothing for the same reasons."}]

'en', 'pageNumber': 0, 'inputText': 'Now 66 Wed 76 Thu 68 Difficult travel and potentially localized flooding expected during the morning commute. by KATIE BENOIT, NBC 10 NEWS JOHNSTON, R.I. (WJAR) — Johnston police are investigating after dozens of hateful white nationalist messages were found on front lawns throughout the town. Similar notes have been left in other areas of Rhode Island over the past year, including neighborhoods in Warwick, Providence, North Kingstown and Barrington. Many Johnston residents on Oak Hill Drive woke up Monday to find plastic bags filled with rocks and white nationalist messages on their property. "First time we ever got this. We have been here over 28 years. So, it\'s the first we got something like this," said Pat Leoncavallo. "I was actually afraid to pick it up because I didn\'t know what it was," one woman said. "I can\'t believe people are going around doing this, I just don\'t understand," she added. The hateful message inside the bags reads, "New Englanders you are being replaced. Organize and resist." It goes on to ask men of European descent to reach out to an email. Johnston police said the flyers are from the group known as the Nationalist Social Club, and they were also found on Green Valley Drive, Brenda Drive and Greenville Avenue. "That\'s abhorrent. I think they are in the wrong city. This is a very ethnic city. This is not a white Anglo-Saxon, protestant city. There is a lot of Italians here, a lot of Latinos, so they are in the wrong city, and I think they are in the wrong state," said Johnston Mayor Joseph Polisena Jr. The flyers appeared on the day a Christopher Columbus statue that previously stood in Providence was unveiled at its new home in town. Meanwhile, there is chaos unfolding thousands of miles away as Israel goes to war. "Too many things going on in this world right now," Leoncavallo said. Johnston police said they are continuing to investigate to find who is responsible.'}]
